questions.text: Assertion (A): Myocarditis is the common known complication of faucial diphtheria Reason (R) : It is due to bacteremia by diphtheria (INICET MAY 2024)

options.label: A
options.text: Assertion is true, reason is true; reason is the correct explanation for the assertion

options.label: B
options.text: Assertion is true, reason is true; reason is not the correct explanation for the assertion

options.label: C
options.text: Assertion is false and reason is also true

options.label: D
options.text: Assertion is true and reason is also false

questions.correct_answer: D. Assertion is true and reason is also false
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Assertion is true and reason is also false

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Assertion: Myocarditis is indeed a common and serious complication of diphtheria, especially in cases of faucial diphtheria. The diphtheria toxin can cause significant damage to the heart muscle, leading to myocarditis.
  • • Assertion:
  • • Reason: The assertion that myocarditis is due to bacteremia by diphtheria is incorrect. Diphtheria does not cause bacteremia. Instead, the complications, including myocarditis, are due to the exotoxin produced by the Corynebacterium diphtheriae. The toxin disseminates through the bloodstream, affecting various organs, including the heart, nerves, and kidneys.
  • • Reason:
  • • Diphtheria Toxin: The pathogenesis of diphtheria involves the production of diphtheria toxin, which is a potent exotoxin. This toxin, rather than the bacteria itself, enters the bloodstream (toxemia) and affects distant organs. Toxemia vs. Bacteremia: Diphtheria is characterized by toxemia, not bacteremia. The bacteria remain localized at the site of infection (e.g., the throat), but the toxin spreads systemically. Myocarditis as a Complication: The diphtheria toxin affects the heart muscle, leading to myocarditis, which is the most common and severe complication of diphtheria. Other complications include neuritis and damage to the adrenal glands.
  • • Diphtheria Toxin: The pathogenesis of diphtheria involves the production of diphtheria toxin, which is a potent exotoxin. This toxin, rather than the bacteria itself, enters the bloodstream (toxemia) and affects distant organs.
  • • Diphtheria Toxin:
  • • Toxemia vs. Bacteremia: Diphtheria is characterized by toxemia, not bacteremia. The bacteria remain localized at the site of infection (e.g., the throat), but the toxin spreads systemically.
  • • Toxemia vs. Bacteremia:
  • • Myocarditis as a Complication: The diphtheria toxin affects the heart muscle, leading to myocarditis, which is the most common and severe complication of diphtheria. Other complications include neuritis and damage to the adrenal glands.
  • • Myocarditis as a Complication:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Assertion is true, reason is true; reason is the correct explanation for the assertion: Incorrect because the reason given is not the correct explanation.
  • • Option A. Assertion is true, reason is true; reason is the correct explanation for the assertion:
  • • Option B. Assertion is true, reason is true; reason is not the correct explanation for the assertion: Incorrect because the reason itself is false.
  • • Option B. Assertion is true, reason is true; reason is not the correct explanation for the assertion:
  • • Option C. Assertion is false and reason is also true: Incorrect because the assertion is true, but the reason is false.
  • • Option C. Assertion is false and reason is also true:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Myocarditis is a common and serious complication of diphtheria due to the effects of the diphtheria toxin. It is important to recognize that the complications arise from toxemia, not bacteremia.

questions.text: A patient presents with severe hydrophobia, a classic symptom of rabies infection. Corneal scrapings are collected for diagnostic testing. Which of the following methods is the most reliable and sensitive for confirming the presence of the rabies virus in this sample? (AIIMS NOV 2016)
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • RT-PCR (Reverse Transcription Polymerase Chain Reaction) is the most sensitive and specific test for diagnosing rabies in various clinical specimens, including corneal scrapings. This molecular technique amplifies and detects the genetic material (RNA) of the rabies virus, providing a definitive diagnosis.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Negri bodies: These are cytoplasmic inclusions found in infected neurons, but their absence does not rule out rabies, and their detection is not as sensitive as RT-PCR. Option B. Antibodies to rabies virus: Antibody detection is less reliable in the early stages of the disease and may not be present in corneal scrapings. Option D. Indirect immunofluorescence: This technique can detect rabies antigens in tissues, but it is less sensitive than RT-PCR and requires specialized expertise.
  • • Option A. Negri bodies: These are cytoplasmic inclusions found in infected neurons, but their absence does not rule out rabies, and their detection is not as sensitive as RT-PCR.
  • • Option A. Negri bodies:
  • • Option B. Antibodies to rabies virus: Antibody detection is less reliable in the early stages of the disease and may not be present in corneal scrapings.
  • • Option B. Antibodies to rabies virus:
  • • Option D. Indirect immunofluorescence: This technique can detect rabies antigens in tissues, but it is less sensitive than RT-PCR and requires specialized expertise.
  • • Option D. Indirect immunofluorescence:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ RT-PCR is the gold standard for diagnosing rabies due to its high sensitivity and specificity. It is the preferred method for detecting the rabies virus in various clinical specimens, including corneal scrapings.

questions.text: A 30-year-old sexually active male presents to the clinic with a genital ulcers that began a week ago. He describes the initial lesion as a small red bump that quickly turned into a sore. On physical examination, multiple superficial ulcers with soft, irregular margins and yellow-gray exudate are noted on the genitalia. The patient also has tender inguinal lymphadenopathy. The physician suspects a sexually transmitted infection and considers testing for the responsible pathogen. Which of the following statements about chancroid are true?

options.label: A
options.text: Chancroid is caused by Treponema pallidum and presents with painless ulcers.

options.label: B
options.text: Chancroid is caused by Haemophilus ducreyi and presents with painful ulcers.

options.label: C
options.text: Chancroid ulcers have hard, indurated edges and do not bleed easily.

options.label: D
options.text: Chancroid lesions do not involve regional lymphadenopathy.

questions.correct_answer: B. Chancroid is caused by Haemophilus ducreyi and presents with painful ulcers.
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Chancroid is a sexually transmitted infection caused by the bacterium Haemophilus ducreyi. It presents as painful, superficial ulcers with irregular, soft margins and a friable base that often bleeds easily. The ulcers are accompanied by regional lymphadenopathy, which may progress to suppuration if untreated. The characteristic appearance of Haemophilus ducreyi on Gram stain, often described as a "school of fish" or "railroad track" pattern, helps in diagnosis. The condition, also known as "soft chancre," is distinguished by its painful nature and soft ulcer margins, unlike other genital ulcer diseases.
  • • Other Options
  • • Other Options
  • • Option A. Chancroid is caused by Treponema pallidum and presents with painless ulcers: This statement describes syphilis, not chancroid. Syphilis is caused by Treponema pallidum and typically presents with painless, hard, indurated ulcers called chancres, which are markedly different from the soft, painful chancroid ulcers.
  • • Option A. Chancroid is caused by Treponema pallidum and presents with painless ulcers:
  • • Option C. Chancroid ulcers have hard, indurated edges and do not bleed easily: Chancroid ulcers are characterized by soft, irregular margins that bleed easily when abraded, unlike syphilitic chancres, which have hard, indurated edges and are typically painless.
  • • Option C. Chancroid ulcers have hard, indurated edges and do not bleed easily:
  • • Option D. Chancroid lesions do not involve regional lymphadenopathy: Chancroid frequently involves regional lymphadenopathy, often painful and tender, which can progress to suppurative buboes if left untreated. This is a key clinical feature that helps differentiate it from other ulcerative STIs.
  • • Option D. Chancroid lesions do not involve regional lymphadenopathy:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Chancroid is caused by Haemophilus ducreyi and presents with painful genital ulcers with soft, irregular margins and associated regional lymphadenopathy. The disease is characterized by its distinct "school of fish" appearance on Gram stain and requires specific growth conditions for culture. Proper identification and differentiation from other sexually transmitted infections are essential for appropriate management.

questions.text: What is the term used to describe a study that is longitudinal, observational, and includes the analysis of variables to determine associations? ( INICET Nov 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Cohort study

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The correct term for a longitudinal, observational study that involves the analysis of variables to determine associations among a group of people is a "cohort study”.
  • • In a cohort study, participants are followed over time to see how different exposures affect their chances of developing an outcome. It's useful for studying the effects of suspected risk factors that cannot be controlled experimentally.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Case-Control Study : This type of study involves identifying participants based on the presence (case) or absence (control) of a particular outcome or disease and then looking back retrospectively to compare exposure to a risk factor or intervention between the groups.
  • • Option A. Case-Control Study
  • • Option C. Ecological Study : These studies assess risk factors or outcomes in a population based on data at the group level, rather than individual data. It's useful for initial, broad correlations between environmental or contextual factors and health outcomes.
  • • Option C. Ecological Study
  • • Option D. Randomized Controlled Trial (RCT) : This is an experimental study where participants are randomly assigned to either the group receiving the intervention or to a control group that does not, to compare outcomes in a controlled way.
  • • Option D. Randomized Controlled Trial (RCT)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ For analyzing how various factors might affect health outcomes over time within a specified group, a cohort study is typically the most appropriate method due to its ability to follow participants through time and observe changes and outcomes as they occur naturally.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman from Himachal Pradesh presents to the dermatology clinic with a progressively enlarging verrucous skin lesion on her leg. She recalls a thorn prick in the same area about a year ago. The lesion has gradually become wart-like, with rough, raised edges. The patient denies any systemic symptoms. A biopsy of the lesion was performed, and the histopathological findings are shown in the image. Which of the following is the most likely causative organism?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The clinical history, geographic background, and histopathological findings strongly suggest Chromoblastomycosis, a chronic subcutaneous fungal infection often seen in tropical and subtropical regions. This condition is commonly associated with traumatic inoculation, such as thorn pricks. The histopathological image shows characteristic dark sclerotic bodies, also known as Medlar bodies or copper penny bodies, which are pathognomonic for Chromoblastomycosis. Phialophora verrucosa is one of the common causative agents of this condition, along with other dematiaceous fungi like Fonsecaea pedrosoi and Cladophialophora carrionii.
  • • Other Options
  • • Other Options
  • • Option A. Sporothrix schenckii: Sporothrix schenckii is the causative agent of sporotrichosis, which typically presents with nodular lesions along lymphatic channels after a traumatic inoculation such as a thorn prick. However, it is characterized histologically by cigar-shaped yeast forms and does not show the sclerotic bodies typical of Chromoblastomycosis.
  • • Option A. Sporothrix schenckii:
  • • Option C. Mycobacterium leprae: Mycobacterium leprae causes leprosy, which is characterized by skin lesions, peripheral nerve involvement, and a different histopathological appearance, usually with granulomatous inflammation and the presence of acid-fast bacilli. It does not present with the sclerotic bodies seen in Chromoblastomycosis.
  • • Option C. Mycobacterium leprae:
  • • Option D. Blastomyces dermatitidis: Blastomycosis, caused by Blastomyces dermatitidis, is a systemic fungal infection that primarily affects the lungs but can disseminate to the skin. It presents with broad-based budding yeast in tissue samples, not the dark sclerotic bodies associated with Chromoblastomycosis.
  • • Option D. Blastomyces dermatitidis:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Chromoblastomycosis is a chronic fungal infection caused by traumatic inoculation of dematiaceous fungi, characterized histologically by dark sclerotic bodies known as Medlar bodies. It presents with verrucous skin lesions and requires antifungal therapy or surgical excision for management. Identification of the characteristic histological findings is crucial for accurate diagnosis and differentiation from other subcutaneous infections.

questions.text: The correct pair of lymph node level in the neck and anatomical boundaries amongst the following are? ( AIIMS Nov 2018)

options.label: C
options.text: Level 5 - Base of skull to cricoid

questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Level 6 - Hyoid to clavicle

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The correct pair of lymph nodes and levels among the following options are level 6- Hyoid to clavicle.
  • • Level 6 lymph nodes are the anterior or central compartment nodes. They span from the hyoid bone (superiorly) to the sternum/clavicle (inferiorly), and from the carotid arteries laterally. This group includes pretracheal, paratracheal, and precricoid (Delphian) nodes. These nodes often come into consideration in thyroid cancers and some laryngeal and hypopharyngeal malignancies.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Level 3 - Cricoid to clavicle: This is incorrect. Level 3 lymph nodes are located in the middle jugular region, and their anatomical boundaries are the lower border of the hyoid bone (superiorly) and the lower border of the cricoid cartilage (inferiorly). They are situated along the middle third of the sternocleidomastoid muscle.
  • • Option A. Level 3 - Cricoid to clavicle:
  • • Option B. Level 4 - Hyoid to cricoid: This is also incorrect. Level 4 lymph nodes are the lower jugular nodes, and their anatomical boundaries are the lower border of the cricoid cartilage (superiorly) and the clavicle (inferiorly). These nodes are situated along the inferior third of the sternocleidomastoid muscle.
  • • Option B. Level 4 - Hyoid to cricoid:
  • • Option C. Level 5 - Base of skull to cricoid: This is not correct. Level 5 lymph nodes are located in the posterior triangle of the neck, which is bound by the sternocleidomastoid muscle (anteriorly), the trapezius muscle (posteriorly), and the clavicle (inferiorly). Level 5 is further divided into Level 5A (located above the cricoid) and Level 5B (located below the cricoid to the clavicle). So, Level 5 spans from the base of the skull to the clavicle.
  • • Option C. Level 5 - Base of skull to cricoid:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Lymph node level in the neck and their anatomical boundaries -
  • ➤ Lymph node level in the neck and their anatomical boundaries -
  • ➤ To aid in the description and localization of lymph nodes, especially in cancer treatment and surgery, they have been categorized into specific levels. Each level is defined by anatomical landmarks.

questions.text: Match the following:( INICET Nov 2022)

It is generally performed between 15-18 weeks but may be done later as well. Chorionic Villous Sampling (B-1) : CVS is performed earlier in pregnancy, typically between 10-13 weeks. It involves sampling of placental tissue to test for chromosomal abnormalities and genetic conditions. Fetal Blood Sampling (C-2) : Also known as cordocentesis or percutaneous umbilical blood sampling (PUBS), this procedure is done around 19-20 weeks to obtain fetal blood, often for testing fetal anemia, infections, or genetic conditions. Fetoscopy (D-3) : This procedure involves visualizing the fetus directly in utero and is used in specific circumstances to assess fetal anatomy and perform interventions.

questions.text: A patient was suspected to have acute brucellosis. A serum sample was sent for a standard agglutination test. It came out to be negative initially but after serial dilutions of the serum sample, the test turned out to be positive. Which of the following is responsible for the initial negative test? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Prozone phenomenon

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ The prozone phenomenon, responsible for initial false-negative results in serological tests like the standard agglutination test for brucellosis, occurs due to excessive antibodies preventing visible agglutination. This can be corrected by diluting the serum, which highlights the importance of considering antibody concentration in diagnostic testing.

questions.text: Which of the following microorganisms is exclusively dependent on the intracellular environment of a host cell for survival and replication? (AIIMS NOV 2016)
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Coxiella burnetii, the causative agent of Q fever, is an obligate intracellular bacterium. This means it can only survive and replicate within the cells of a host organism. It has adapted to thrive in the harsh environment of phagolysosomes, the intracellular compartments where cells digest foreign material.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Listeria monocytogenes: This bacterium is a facultative intracellular pathogen, meaning it can survive and replicate both inside and outside host cells. Option C. Klebsiella pneumoniae: This bacterium is an extracellular pathogen, primarily residing and multiplying outside of host cells. Option D. Legionella pneumophila: While Legionella pneumophila is an intracellular pathogen, it is not an obligate one. It can survive and replicate in the environment, but it prefers to invade and replicate within macrophages and other host cells.
  • • Option B. Listeria monocytogenes: This bacterium is a facultative intracellular pathogen, meaning it can survive and replicate both inside and outside host cells.
  • • Option B. Listeria monocytogenes:
  • • Option C. Klebsiella pneumoniae: This bacterium is an extracellular pathogen, primarily residing and multiplying outside of host cells.
  • • Option C. Klebsiella pneumoniae:
  • • Option D. Legionella pneumophila: While Legionella pneumophila is an intracellular pathogen, it is not an obligate one. It can survive and replicate in the environment, but it prefers to invade and replicate within macrophages and other host cells.
  • • Option D. Legionella pneumophila:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Coxiella burnetii is unique among the listed organisms as it is an obligate intracellular pathogen, relying entirely on the intracellular environment of a host cell for survival and replication.

questions.text: What is the root value of cremasteric reflex? ( AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. L1, L2

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The cremasteric reflex is mediated through the sensory fibers of the ilioinguinal nerve (L1) and the motor fibers of the genital branch of the genitofemoral nerve (L1, L2). When the inner thigh is stroked, sensory impulses travel via the ilioinguinal nerve to the spinal cord segments L1 and L2, and motor impulses from these segments, through the genital branch of the genitofemoral nerve, cause the cremaster muscle to contract, pulling the testicles upward.
  • • The cremasteric reflex's afferent and efferent branches:
  • • Afferent - Femoral branch of genitofemoral nerve Efferent - Genital branch of genitofemoral nerve
  • • Afferent - Femoral branch of genitofemoral nerve
  • • Afferent
  • • Efferent - Genital branch of genitofemoral nerve
  • • Efferent -
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. T8, T9 : These thoracic spinal nerve roots primarily innervate the muscles and skin of the thoracic region and contribute to the intercostal nerves. They are not involved in the cremasteric reflex.
  • • Option A.
  • • T8, T9
  • • Option C . L3, L4 : These lumbar spinal nerve roots are primarily associated with the front of the thigh and the medial side of the leg and foot. The femoral nerve, which is the largest nerve arising from the lumbar plexus, is derived from these roots. These roots are not directly involved in the cremasteric reflex but are important for the patellar (knee-jerk) reflex.
  • • Option C
  • • L3, L4
  • • Option D . S1, S2 : These sacral spinal nerve roots play a major role in innervating the posterior thigh, most of the leg and foot, and the perineum. They contribute to the sciatic nerve, among others. Reflexes like the ankle jerk (Achilles reflex) involve these nerve roots. They are not associated with the cremasteric reflex.
  • • Option D
  • • S1, S2

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Cremasteric reflex is mediated by L1 and L2. In this reflex, there is ipsilateral elevation of the testicle following stroking of the medial thigh.
  • ➤ Other clinical reflexes and their root values: -
  • ➤ Other clinical reflexes and their root values: -
  • ➤ Achilles reflex – S1, S2
  • ➤ Patellar reflex – L3, L4
  • ➤ Biceps and brachio-radialis reflexes – C5, C6
  • ➤ Triceps reflex – C7, C8
  • ➤ Anal wink reflex – S3, S4
  • ➤ Abdominal reflex – T7 – T12

questions.text: A 20-year-old woman presented at 7 weeks of gestation, unwilling to continue the pregnancy. What are the drugs used for medical termination of pregnancy in this patient? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Misoprostol and Mifepristone

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Misoprostol and Mifepristone : The drugs used for medical termination of pregnancy (MTP) in this patient presenting at 7 weeks of gestation are misoprostol and mifepristone. Mifepristone 200 mg is administered orally on day 1. It acts as an antiprogestogen, blocking the effects of progesterone, which is essential to maintain pregnancy. Misoprostol is given 24-48 hours after mifepristone. Misoprostol, a prostaglandin E1 analog, induces uterine contractions to expel the pregnancy tissue. Clinical confirmation of MTP is done on day 14 through clinical examination and/or ultrasonography to ensure the complete expulsion of the products of conception.
  • • Misoprostol and Mifepristone : The drugs used for medical termination of pregnancy (MTP) in this patient presenting at 7 weeks of gestation are misoprostol and mifepristone. Mifepristone 200 mg is administered orally on day 1. It acts as an antiprogestogen, blocking the effects of progesterone, which is essential to maintain pregnancy. Misoprostol is given 24-48 hours after mifepristone. Misoprostol, a prostaglandin E1 analog, induces uterine contractions to expel the pregnancy tissue. Clinical confirmation of MTP is done on day 14 through clinical examination and/or ultrasonography to ensure the complete expulsion of the products of conception.
  • • Misoprostol and Mifepristone
  • • The drugs used for medical termination of pregnancy (MTP) in this patient presenting at 7 weeks of gestation are misoprostol and mifepristone. Mifepristone 200 mg is administered orally on day 1. It acts as an antiprogestogen, blocking the effects of progesterone, which is essential to maintain pregnancy. Misoprostol is given 24-48 hours after mifepristone. Misoprostol, a prostaglandin E1 analog, induces uterine contractions to expel the pregnancy tissue. Clinical confirmation of MTP is done on day 14 through clinical examination and/or ultrasonography to ensure the complete expulsion of the products of conception.
  • • The drugs used for medical termination of pregnancy (MTP) in this patient presenting at 7 weeks of gestation are misoprostol and mifepristone.
  • • Mifepristone 200 mg is administered orally on day 1. It acts as an antiprogestogen, blocking the effects of progesterone, which is essential to maintain pregnancy.
  • • Misoprostol is given 24-48 hours after mifepristone. Misoprostol, a prostaglandin E1 analog, induces uterine contractions to expel the pregnancy tissue.
  • • Clinical confirmation of MTP is done on day 14 through clinical examination and/or ultrasonography to ensure the complete expulsion of the products of conception.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Misoprostol and Medroxyprogesterone : Medroxyprogesterone is a synthetic progestin used in contraception and hormone replacement therapy but is not used in medical termination of pregnancy.
  • • Option A. Misoprostol and Medroxyprogesterone
  • • Option C. Mifepristone and Methotrexate : Methotrexate is a folate antagonist that can be used in combination with misoprostol for medical termination of pregnancy, especially in early gestations, but it is not the standard regimen compared to mifepristone and misoprostol.
  • • Option C. Mifepristone and Methotrexate
  • • Option D. Mifepristone and Medroxyprogesterone : Medroxyprogesterone is not used in medical termination of pregnancy.
  • • Option D. Mifepristone and Medroxyprogesterone

questions.text: A female patient presents to the clinic with a painful lump in her breast that has been increasing in size over the past few days. After examination, the doctor diagnoses her with a breast abscess and prescribes antibiotics to help clear the infection. The doctor attempts to aspirate the abscess using a needle and syringe, but no fluid is obtained. What is the next step in management? (NEET PG 2019)

options.label: D
options.text: Stop antibiotics as no aspirate was collected

questions.correct_answer: C. A second attempt at aspiration
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. A second attempt at aspiration

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • If the first attempt at aspiration fails to obtain fluid, the next logical step is to attempt aspiration again, potentially with ultrasound guidance. Ultrasound guidance can enhance the accuracy of the procedure by allowing direct visualization of the abscess, ensuring that the needle is correctly positioned to access the abscess cavity. This method is less invasive than incision and drainage (I&D), making it a preferred option if it can effectively manage the abscess.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Incision and Drainage: Incision and drainage is generally considered if aspiration fails repeatedly or if the abscess is too large. While effective, it is not typically the immediate next step after a single failed aspiration attempt. It is more invasive than aspiration and usually reserved for cases where less invasive methods are unsuccessful.
  • • Option A. Incision and Drainage:
  • • Option B. Continue antibiotics only: Antibiotics are crucial in managing breast abscesses by treating the underlying infection. However, they alone might not suffice for large or dense abscesses. The pus trapped within the abscess often needs to be physically removed to expedite healing and provide symptom relief. Continuing antibiotics without addressing the abscess can lead to prolonged infection and discomfort.
  • • Option B. Continue antibiotics only:
  • • Option D. Stop antibiotics as no aspirate was collected: This option is not recommended. The failure to collect aspirate does not imply the absence of infection. The antibiotics were prescribed based on the clinical diagnosis of a breast abscess, and stopping them prematurely could allow the infection to worsen. Continuation of antibiotics is important until the course is complete or unless indicated otherwise by a physician.
  • • Option D. Stop antibiotics as no aspirate was collected:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ If the initial aspiration attempt for a breast abscess fails, the next step should be to attempt aspiration again, preferably under ultrasound guidance, before considering more invasive procedures like incision and drainage. This approach ensures accurate access to the abscess and minimizes invasiveness.

questions.text: Which of the following organisms is known to produce urease, aiding in its survival in acidic environments?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Helicobacter pylori is a well-known urease-producing bacterium that survives in the acidic environment of the stomach. Urease hydrolyzes urea into ammonia and carbon dioxide, which neutralizes gastric acid, creating a protective niche for H. pylori. This enzymatic action is critical for the bacterium's colonization and contributes to its pathogenicity, leading to conditions such as peptic ulcers and chronic gastritis. The detection of urease activity, such as with a urease breath test, is commonly used to diagnose H. pylori infection.
  • • Other Options
  • • Other Options
  • • Option A) Escherichia coli: E. coli does not produce urease. Although it is commonly associated with gastrointestinal and urinary tract infections, it lacks the urease enzyme and does not utilize urea hydrolysis for survival or pathogenicity.
  • • Option A) Escherichia coli:
  • • Option C) Streptococcus pneumoniae: This organism is a common cause of respiratory infections such as pneumonia, but it does not produce urease. Its pathogenic mechanisms involve capsule formation, pneumolysin production, and adherence factors, not urease activity.
  • • Option C) Streptococcus pneumoniae:
  • • Option D) Pseudomonas aeruginosa: Pseudomonas is a versatile bacterium known for its resistance to antibiotics and biofilm formation, but it does not produce urease. Its pathogenicity is primarily driven by toxins and other virulence factors unrelated to urease.
  • • Option D) Pseudomonas aeruginosa:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Helicobacter pylori produces urease, an enzyme that helps it survive in the acidic environment of the stomach by converting urea into ammonia and carbon dioxide, thus neutralizing stomach acid. This enzymatic activity is pivotal for its pathogenicity in conditions such as peptic ulcers and chronic gastritis.
  • ➤ Urease-producing organisms : (Mnemonic-PUNCH)
  • ➤ Urease-producing organisms
  • ➤ Proteus Ureoplasma urealyticum Nocardia Cryptococcus, Corynebacterium urealyticum H. pylori
  • ➤ Proteus
  • ➤ Ureoplasma urealyticum
  • ➤ Nocardia
  • ➤ Cryptococcus, Corynebacterium urealyticum
  • ➤ H. pylori

questions.text: Topiramate is used for? ( INICET May 2021
questions.correct_answer: B. Treatment of Lennox Gastaut syndrome
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Treatment of Lennox Gastaut syndrome

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Topiramate is primarily used for the treatment of Lennox-Gastaut syndrome, a severe form of epilepsy in children. It is also used for the prophylaxis of migraines, reducing alcohol cravings, aiding in weight loss, and as an adjunct therapy for bipolar disorder.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man with a history of frequent international travel, particularly to rural areas in South Asia and Africa, presents with prolonged fever, weight loss, and abdominal discomfort. Physical examination reveals hepatosplenomegaly. A bone marrow aspirate is performed, and the findings are shown in the image below. Which investigation would be the most appropriate for confirming the diagnosis in this patient?
questions.correct_answer: C. rK39 antigen test for Leishmaniasis
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The image shows macrophages infested with intracellular Leishmania donovani bodies, characterized by the presence of kinetoplasts and a characteristic double dot appearance (Leishman stain), suggestive of visceral leishmaniasis (VL). Leishmaniasis is caused by protozoan parasites transmitted through the bite of infected female phlebotomine sandflies. The rK39 antigen test is a rapid and highly specific immunochromatographic test that detects anti-k39 antibodies, which are secreted in various body fluids, including blood, and is widely used for diagnosing VL. The test offers a quick, sensitive, and specific diagnosis, making it the investigation of choice for confirming visceral leishmaniasis.
  • • Other Options
  • • Other Options
  • • Option A. Blood smear for malaria parasites: Although malaria is a common cause of fever in travelers, the bone marrow findings and clinical presentation are not consistent with malaria. Malaria typically shows ring forms, trophozoites, and schizonts in peripheral blood smears rather than intracellular bodies as seen in leishmaniasis.
  • • Option A. Blood smear for malaria parasites:
  • • Option B. Tuberculin skin test (Mantoux test): This test is used for diagnosing latent tuberculosis infection but is not relevant in this case. Tuberculosis does not present with intracellular protozoa in bone marrow aspirates and is not transmitted by sandflies.
  • • Option B. Tuberculin skin test (Mantoux test):
  • • Option D. HIV serology: Although HIV can cause prolonged fever and weight loss, the bone marrow findings do not suggest HIV-related changes. HIV is not diagnosed through the identification of Leishmania parasites in the bone marrow, and the clinical scenario strongly points toward visceral leishmaniasis.
  • • Option D. HIV serology:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Visceral leishmaniasis should be considered in patients with fever of unknown origin, hepatosplenomegaly, and travel history to endemic areas. The rK39 antigen test is a rapid and specific diagnostic tool for visceral leishmaniasis, detecting antibodies against the parasite’s antigens. Bone marrow or splenic aspirate showing intracellular Leishmania bodies remains the gold standard for confirmation.

questions.text: What will the corrected reticulocyte count if Hb is 5 g/dl and absolute reticulocyte count is 9%? (INICET NOV 2022)

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: A patient is planned to undergo hysteroscopic polypectomy using bipolar electrocautery. What is the ideal agent for distention? (NEET PG 2020)

questions.text: Which of the following investigations does not use antibody marking? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Hemagglutination Test

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The hemagglutination test is unique in its use of direct interactions between particles (like viruses) and red blood cells to demonstrate binding and agglutination, distinguishing it from other tests that rely on labeled antibodies to indicate the presence of specific antigens or antibodies. This method is particularly useful in blood typing and viral detection.

questions.text: A 28-year primigravida presents at 36 weeks with painful vulval ulcers. She does not give history of similar lesions ever in the past. On examination, there are multiple painful vesicular lesions. Which is the best treatment option? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.correct_answer: A. Acyclovir and elective Cesarean section
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Acyclovir and elective Cesarean section

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Acyclovir and elective Cesarean section:
  • • Acyclovir and elective Cesarean section:
  • • The diagnosis in this woman is genital herpes simplex (HSV). Since she has never had similar lesions in the past, this is primary genital herpes. The risk of neonatal infection following vaginal delivery with primary HSV is very high (up to 50%). Neonatal herpes has a very high mortality rate. Antivirals (Acyclovir) have to be started. Hence, the recommended mode of delivery in primary HSV is elective Cesarean section to prevent transmission to the neonate.
  • • The diagnosis in this woman is genital herpes simplex (HSV).
  • • Since she has never had similar lesions in the past, this is primary genital herpes.
  • • The risk of neonatal infection following vaginal delivery with primary HSV is very high (up to 50%). Neonatal herpes has a very high mortality rate.
  • • Antivirals (Acyclovir) have to be started.
  • • Hence, the recommended mode of delivery in primary HSV is elective Cesarean section to prevent transmission to the neonate.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Acyclovir and induction of labor: While acyclovir is appropriate for treating HSV, inducing labor is not recommended due to the high risk of neonatal infection with vaginal delivery in the presence of active primary HSV lesions.
  • • Option B. Acyclovir and induction of labor:
  • • Option C. Spontaneous delivery: Spontaneous vaginal delivery poses a significant risk of neonatal herpes, which can lead to severe complications and high mortality. This is not recommended in the case of primary genital HSV.
  • • Option C. Spontaneous delivery:
  • • Option D. Antiviral and normal vaginal delivery: Antiviral treatment is necessary, but normal vaginal delivery is not recommended due to the high risk of transmitting HSV to the neonate. Cesarean section is the preferred mode of delivery.
  • • Option D. Antiviral and normal vaginal delivery:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cases of primary genital herpes simplex virus (HSV) infection at term, the best treatment option is to start antiviral therapy and plan for an elective Cesarean section to reduce the risk of neonatal herpes infection.
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 673, High Risk Pregnancy: Management Options; David James, Philip J Steer; 5 th edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 673, High Risk Pregnancy: Management Options; David James, Philip J Steer; 5 th edition

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman visits the infertility clinic with a complaint of recurrent abortions. Upon investigations, she is found to have a septate uterus. Which of the following corrective procedures has the best obstetric outcome? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Transcervical resection of septum

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Transcervical hysteroscopic resection of the septum has the best obstetric outcome. The procedure involves the resection of the septum under hysteroscopic guidance. Hence, it doesn't scar the uterus and avoids the necessity of Cesarean sections for future pregnancies improving the obstetric outcomes.
  • • Transcervical hysteroscopic resection of the septum has the best obstetric outcome.
  • • The procedure involves the resection of the septum under hysteroscopic guidance. Hence, it doesn't scar the uterus and avoids the necessity of Cesarean sections for future pregnancies improving the obstetric outcomes.
  • • Other Options
  • • Other Options
  • • Metroplasty is a type of unification procedures in mullerian anomalies
  • • Option A. Jones metroplasty and Option C. Tompkins metroplasty are for septate uterus but are not preferred now. As now the treatment of choice is hysteroscopic resection of the septa.
  • • Option A. Jones metroplasty
  • • Option C. Tompkins metroplasty
  • • Option B. Strassman metroplasty : Strassman metroplasty is for bicornuate uterus.
  • • Option B. Strassman metroplasty

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Transcervical hysteroscopic resection of the septum is the best corrective procedure for a septate uterus to improve obstetric outcomes, as it does not scar the uterus and allows for future vaginal deliveries.
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 659, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology, 6 th edition
